choices: determine the vehicleâ€™s speed at the time of impact.
assess the severity of the third collision of the crash.
identify contact points and predict potential injuries.
recognize if the driver hit the brakes before impact.
front.question: Evaluation of the interior of a crashed motor vehicle during extrication will allow the EMT to:

cards.back: identify contact points and predict potential injuries.

choices: be involved in trauma prevention programs.
have general surgeons in-house 24 hours a day.
be able to stabilize patients before transferring to a higher level facility.
have access to an emergency physician within 30 minutes.
front.question: In contrast to a Level III trauma center, a Level I trauma center must:

cards.back: have general surgeons in-house 24 hours a day.

front.question: Signs of a pulmonary blast injury include:

cards.back: coughing up blood.

choices: bilateral hip fractures usually occur when an elderly person falls.
any fall in the elderly is considered to be high-energy trauma.
osteoporosis can cause a fracture as a result of a fall from a standing position.
elderly patients who fall usually have a secondary head injury.
front.question: When assessing an elderly patient who fell, it is important to remember that:

cards.back: osteoporosis can cause a fracture as a result of a fall from a standing position.

choices: be used with or without a shoulder harness.
prevent a second collision inside the car.
prevent the driver from sustaining head trauma.
decrease the severity of deceleration injuries.
front.question: Airbags are designed to:

cards.back: decrease the severity of deceleration injuries.

choices: transport the survivors only if they have injuries or complain of pain.
rapidly assess only the survivors who have experienced obvious trauma.
allow the survivors to refuse transport if they have no obvious injuries.
suspect that all living occupants experienced the same serious trauma.
front.question: If one or more occupants in the same vehicle are killed in a crash, the EMT should:

cards.back: suspect that all living occupants experienced the same serious trauma.

choices: Rapid transport to a trauma center
front.question: Which of the following interventions is the MOST critical to the outcome of a patient with multisystem trauma?

cards.back: Rapid transport to a trauma center

choices: the way in which traumatic injuries occur.
the detection of less obvious life-threatening injuries.
a predictable pattern that leads to serious injuries.
your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying injuries.
front.question: The index of suspicion is MOST accurately defined as:

cards.back: your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying injuries.

front.question: Which of the following findings would be LEAST suggestive of the presence of high-energy trauma?

cards.back: Deployment of the airbag

choices: exit wounds caused by the bullet are usually small.
the bullet may tumble or ricochet within the body.
the area of damage is usually smaller than the bullet.
the caliber of the bullet is frequently unknown.
front.question: Internal injuries caused by gunshot wounds are difficult to predict because:

cards.back: the bullet may tumble or ricochet within the body.

front.question: When assessing the interior of a crashed motor vehicle for damage, you are gathering information regarding the:

cards.back: mechanism of injury.

front.question: Which of the following would MOST likely occur as the direct result of the second collision in a motor vehicle crash?

cards.back: Deformed steering wheel

choices: has a bleeding disorder or takes anticoagulant medications and has any blunt or penetrating injury.
has a systolic blood pressure of less than 110 mm Hg or a heart rate greater than 110 beats/min.
was involved in a motor vehicle crash in which another patient in the same vehicle was killed.
has a GCS score of less than or equal to 13 with a mechanism attributed to trauma.
front.question: According to the American College of Surgeons Committee on Trauma (ACS-COT), an adult trauma patient should be transported to the highest level of trauma center if he or she:

cards.back: has a GCS score of less than or equal to 13 with a mechanism attributed to trauma.

front.question: Force acting over a distance is the definition of:

cards.back: work.

front.question: The phenomenon of pressure waves emanating from the bullet, causing damage remote from its path, is known as:

cards.back: cavitation.

choices: is wearing only a lap belt.
front.question: A driver involved in a rollover motor vehicle crash will MOST likely experience serious injuries or death if he or she:

cards.back: is ejected or partially ejected.

front.question: Factors that should be considered when assessing a patient who has fallen include all of the following, EXCEPT:

cards.back: the speed of the fall.

front.question: The energy of a moving object is called:

cards.back: kinetic energy.

choices: use a demand valve to ventilate the patient.
avoid giving oxygen under positive pressure.
administer large amounts of intravenous fluid.
front.question: When treating a patient who experienced a pulmonary blast injury, you should:

cards.back: avoid giving oxygen under positive pressure.

front.question: When the speed of a motor vehicle doubles, the amount of kinetic energy:

cards.back: quadruples.
